instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont post
threads.message: Hello. I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that was originally stuck on 5v. I had to replace both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and got 20v back and the board booted and it seemed to be working fine. Then I restarted it and tried to run apple diagnostics and during the test, the computer just turned off and would not turn back on. I immediately checked for a short on PPBUS and it was now shorted. I compared diode mode values on the large coils and found the short was on <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>. Replaced that and the short on PPBUS was gone but now when I try to turn it on again, it does not seem to post. It seems to be taking the correct amps for a working board (300-600ma), but has no USB activity or cap lock reaction. All the rails seem to be working correctly, but I did find that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is showing a low diode mode reading compared to a good board. Diode mode reading is about .050 but it does have 3.3v still. I tried to inject up to 4v into the line but nothing really gets hot. I am wondering if the low diode mode reading is a indication of an issue even though the voltage is present. Should I just start removing things connected to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> until the diode mode reading goes back to normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont post
threads.message:
Overvoltage went to CPU when <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> got burnt.
Low resistance on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> could be result of bad CPU now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont post
threads.message: Damn that's what I was afraid of. I was not sure since it looks like its using the correct amps as a good board and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> does not go directly to the CPU.
